brief_summary.textblock:
We are interested in studying whether and how medical problems other than primary cancer
      before hematopoietic cell transplantation would impact the profiles of quality of life and
      toxicities post-transplantation for patients with blood cancers. We want to see if by
      assessing comorbidities (such as diabetes) early on, we can identify those patients who will
      have more toxicities or limitations in their quality of life after transplant. The generated
      information could set the stage for future intervention studies aiming to improve quality of
      life for patients with blood cancers after transplantation.

clinical_study.brief_title: Associations Between Pre-transplant Comorbidities and Post-transplant Toxicities and Quality of Life

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Allogeneic HCT candidates who are >18 years of age

          -  Able to speak and read English

          -  Able to provide informed consent

          -  Access to a telephone for study-related communications

          -  Diagnosed with a hematological malignant disease

          -  Willing to complete survey packets at 5 time-points, spanning two years

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  HCT candidates who are 18 years or younger at the time of study enrollment

          -  HCT candidates who cannot read, write, or speak English

          -  Patients with diagnoses of non-malignant diseases, or solid tumors are primary
             disease

study_pop.textblock:
Patients diagnosed with hematological malignancies who are being treated with allogeneic
        hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) at the Seattle Cancer Care Alliance.

clinical_study.official_title: Prospective Assessment of Associations Between Pre-transplant Comorbidities and Post-transplant Toxicities and Quality of Life

primary_outcome.description: A 19-item instrument, it assesses physical symptoms and their interference with life.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline in Symptoms at 3,6,12,and 24 months

primary_outcome.description: A 49-item questionnaire measuring quality of life in bone marrow transplant patients, it measures physical, functional, social/family and emotional well-being in addition to bone marrow transplant-specific concerns.
primary_outcome.measure: The Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy Bone Marrow Transplant Scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline in Symptoms at 3,6,12,and 24 months

primary_outcome.description: This measure is used to measure utilities that can be used to calculate a quality adjusted survival score.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline in Symptoms at 3,6,12,and 24 months

primary_outcome.description: This measure captures the frequency and diversity of social activities outside of daily responsibilities.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline in Symptoms at 3,6,12,and 24 months

primary_outcome.description: This measures social support, including participation in social activities and perception of social support.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline in Symptoms at 3,6,12,and 24 months

primary_outcome.description: This is a 25-item scale assessing distress related to perceived demands from events specific to cancer survivors.
primary_outcome.measure: The Cancer and Treatment Distress Scale
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline in Symptoms at 3,6,12,and 24 months

primary_outcome.description: The PHQ-9 measures measures depression and parallels the nine diagnostic symptom criteria of the DSM-IV for Major Depressive Disorder.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change from Baseline in Symptoms at 3,6,12,and 24 months

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: We will measure toxicities using the NCI CTCAE
secondary_outcome.measure: National Cancer Institute's Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (NCI CTCAE)

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)
